name: Kepler-235
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-235 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-235 is a star with 0.4499999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.55 times its radius. It is located 1413.04 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-235 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-235 b

Kepler-235 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.34 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-235.

The mass of Kepler-235 b is 6.60 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-235 b is 2.23 that of Earth. At 6.60 Earth masses, Kepler-235 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-235 c

Kepler-235 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.82 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-235.

The mass of Kepler-235 c is 1.73 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-235 c is 1.28 that of Earth. At 1.73 Earth masses, Kepler-235 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-235 d

Kepler-235 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.06 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-235.

The mass of Kepler-235 d is 5.40 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-235 d is 2.05 that of Earth. At 5.40 Earth masses, Kepler-235 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-235 e

Kepler-235 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.21 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 46.18 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-235.

The mass of Kepler-235 e is 6.52 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-235 e is 2.22 that of Earth. At 6.52 Earth masses, Kepler-235 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.213 astronomical units, and a mass of 6.52 Earth masses, Kepler-235 e could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-235, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
